newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Oct 22.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Oct 22.

text.p: Avery Dennison Corp plans to report record third-quarter profit and sales as well as recommend a stock split and dividend increase, the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.
The newspaper said Avery will report a net income for the quarter totalling $46.6 million or $0.89 per share.
- The United States might lose a challenge made against its quota on underwear imported from Costa Rica in a case brought before the World Trade Organization.
- General Motors Corp and the Canadian Automobile Workers union are close to reaching an agreement to end a 19-day strike.
- Seagram Co Ltd and Viacom Inc are trying to settle a lawsuit over their jointly owned cable television networks.
- Investors are expected to buy up some large stock offerings in Europe this week including one to be made by from Russian natural gas company Gazprom.
- Japanese authorities are about to file charges against Yasuo Hamanaka, former Sumitomo copper trader who is at the center of a trading scandal.
- IBM Corp's quarterly profit was a little higher than analyst expectations but the current quarter might take a revenue hit as customers lease mainframes rather than buy them.
- Microsoft Corp reported earnings that were better than the market expected.
- Oil companies like Exxon Corp, Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc reported higher quarterly profits.
- RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp reported a 4.0-percent increase in quarterly profit.
- Integrated Health Services Inc agreed to acquire Coram Healthcare Corp for $280 million in stock and the assumption of $375 million in debt.
- Molten Metal Technology Inc's stock fell 49 percent after the U.S. Department of Energy declined to renew a reasearch pact with it.
- U.S. Postal Service's top advertizing official left the service after an internal audit disclosed that his department overspent its budget.

- Some investors complain that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc took advantage of a trying period in FlightSafety International Inc's earnings to get a bargain price for the pilot-training company.
- The Dow Jones industrial average ended 3.36 points down at 6,090.87 as trading closely followed IBM's presentation.
- U.S. bond market traded sluggishly as it got ready to bid on more than $30 billion of new government securities.
